verses.text: O LORD, God of vengeance, God of vengeance, shine forth!
verses.comment: The psalm opens by addressing God as the true Judge, a theme connecting to God's justice in the Law and prophets. The double emphasis on 'God of vengeance' highlights a plea for righteous retribution. Compare with Ps. 50:2 where the LORD is described as shining forth from Zion.

verses.text: Rise up, O Judge of the earth; repay the proud what they deserve!
verses.comment: 'Judge of the earth' points to God's universal authority over all nations. This is a foreshadowing of Christ's future judgment at His return (cf. Matt. 25:31).

verses.text: How long, O LORD, shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked exult?
verses.comment: The repetition of 'how long' expresses deep suffering and longing for justice. Habakkuk echoes this sentiment, asking God about the delay in His judgment over evil.

verses.text: They pour out arrogant words; all evildoers boast.
verses.comment: The proud speech of the wicked is a recurring theme (Ps. 73:8-9), aligning with warnings against pride found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: They crush your people, O LORD, and afflict your inheritance.
verses.comment: 'Your inheritance' refers to Israel as God's chosen people—foreshadowing the Church as the new people of God. See Ps. 28:9, a prayer for blessing God's heritage.

verses.text: They kill the widow and the foreigner, and murder the fatherless.
verses.comment: God's concern for the marginalized—widows, foreigners, orphans—remains central in both Old and New Testaments. Cf. Ex. 22:21-22 where Israel is commanded to protect them.

verses.text: And they say, 'The LORD does not see; the God of Jacob does not notice.'
verses.comment: This verse reveals the flawed thinking of the wicked—denying God's omniscience. God's seeing and judging is assured throughout scripture.

verses.text: Understand, O dullest of the people! Fools, when will you be wise?
verses.comment: The psalmist rebukes ignorance; wisdom is repeatedly linked with the fear of the Lord (Prov. 1:7).

verses.text: He who planted the ear, does he not hear? He who formed the eye, does he not see?
verses.comment: The argument appeals to God’s creative power—He who made senses surely exercises them perfectly. A clear teaching of God’s omniscience and omnipresence.

verses.text: He who disciplines nations, does he not rebuke? He who teaches man knowledge?
verses.comment: God's role as educator and disciplinarian for all humanity finds echoes in Ps. 2:10—rulers are urged to seek wisdom from the LORD.

verses.text: The LORD knows the thoughts of man, that they are but breath.
verses.comment: 'But breath' (or vanity) contrasts human frailty with divine wisdom; Paul cites this in 1 Cor. 3:20 against human boasting.

verses.text: Blessed is the man whom you discipline, O LORD, and whom you teach out of your law,
verses.comment: Discipline from God is a sign of love and blessing. Heb. 12:6 and Prov. 3:11-12 reflect this as evidence of being God's true children.

verses.text: to give him rest from days of trouble, until a pit is dug for the wicked.
verses.comment: God's instruction brings peace even amid suffering, looking forward to the ultimate triumph of the righteous over the wicked.

verses.text: For the LORD will not abandon his people; he will not forsake his inheritance.
verses.comment: A promise of God's eternal faithfulness—see also Lk. 1:33, where the people of God are given eternal security under Christ's reign.

verses.text: For judgment will return to righteousness, and all the upright in heart will follow it.
verses.comment: Judgment and righteousness are united in God’s will; the upright are called to pursue God's justice, anticipating its fullness in Christ.

verses.text: Who rises up for me against the wicked? Who stands up for me against evildoers?
verses.comment: A cry for help, urging God or godly people to act for justice. Spiritual warfare and solidarity among the faithful are implied.

verses.text: If the LORD had not been my help, my soul would soon have lived in the land of silence.
verses.comment: The 'land of silence' refers to death or Sheol; God’s rescue preserves life—a shadow of resurrection hope.

verses.text: When I said, 'My foot is slipping,' your steadfast love, O LORD, held me up.
verses.comment: God's unchanging love supports the faithful in weakness, a theme fulfilled in Christ’s saving work.

verses.text: When the cares of my heart are many, your consolations cheer my soul.
verses.comment: God’s comfort personalizes His care, and points toward Jesus' invitation to the weary to find rest in Him.

verses.text: Can wicked rulers be allied with you, those who frame injustice by statute?
verses.comment: Condemnation of corrupt authority: true justice cannot coexist with evil. This echoes the prophetic challenge to unjust leadership.

verses.text: They band together against the life of the righteous and condemn the innocent to death.
verses.comment: This verse looks forward to Christ’s own condemnation, though He was righteous—fulfilled in the passion narrative (Matt. 27:24).

verses.text: But the LORD has become my stronghold, and my God the rock of my refuge.
verses.comment: Imagery of God as a fortress speaks to ultimate dependence on Him—a foreshadowing of spiritual protection found in union with the Lord.

verses.text: He will bring back on them their own wickedness and destroy them in their evil; the LORD our God will wipe them out.
verses.comment: God's perfect justice ensures that evil is ultimately overcome. The finality of God’s judgment points toward the eschatological hope in the New Testament.
